Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 17.0, Believable Character Actions: 14.0, Nuanced Characters: 11.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 15.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 13.0, Elegant Prose: 12.0, Emotionally Engaging: 13.0, Emotionally Complex: 10.0, Coherent: 16.0, Meandering: 5.0, Weak Dialogue: 8.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 7.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 9.0, Amateurish: 6.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 14.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 15.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 14.0, Overall Impression: 13.0
+ Young adult drama: Gone South — Score: 68.8
Prompt:
Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The strap on my backpack keeps slipping off my shoulder, like it's trying to make a run for it too. I can't blame it; everything feels so uncertain, so shaky. I just want to grab it with both hands—hell, hug it to my chest—and make it stay. But I can't. I have to keep moving. New Orleans is a different planet from that shitty town in Tennessee. The air is thick with humidity and the smell of something sweet and rotten all at once. The streets are narrow, the buildings old and dripping with history—or maybe it's just the mold. I've never seen anything like it. My stomach growls, reminding me I haven't eaten since... God, I don't even know. Before I left. Before I came out to Mom and Dad and everything went to shit. I see a dumpster behind a café. I've never dumpster-dived before, but there's a first time for everything, right? I hoist myself up, trying to be casual, like I'm just a teenager hanging out by a dumpster for fun. Inside, it's not as gross as I thought. There's a bunch of bagels in a plastic bag, probably from yesterday. I grab them and jump down, feeling a mix of triumph and disgust. "You new here?" The voice makes me jump. I turn to see a girl leaning against the wall, smirking at me. She's got short, spiky hair dyed a faded purple, a nose ring, and eyes that are way too old for her face. "What gave it away?" I say, slinging the bagels into my backpack. She laughs, pushing off the wall and coming closer. "You've got that deer-in-the-headlights look. Plus, nobody actually from here would dumpster-dive in broad daylight." I shrug, trying to play it cool. "Guess I'm still learning the rules." She sticks out her hand. "I'm Alex. Short for Alexandra, but if you call me that, I'll kick your ass." I laugh and shake her hand. "Taylor." Alex raises an eyebrow. "Just Taylor?" I hesitate, then nod. "Yeah. Just Taylor." She studies me for a second, then nods back. "Cool. You want to get out of the alley and go somewhere less... trashy?" I smirk. "Lead the way." We end up in a little park by the river. It's weirdly peaceful, considering the chaos of the French Quarter just a few blocks away. Alex pulls out a pack of cigarettes and offers me one. I shake my head. "Don't smoke," I say. She shrugs and lights up. "So, what's your story, Taylor?" I watch the river flow by, all murky and slow. "I'm from Tennessee. I came out to my parents a couple of days ago. It didn't go well." Alex blows out a stream of smoke. "Came out? As in...?" "Trans," I say, bracing myself for her reaction. She just nods. "Cool. So they kicked you out?" I shake my head. "Not exactly. They just... didn't take it well. I couldn't stay there anymore." Alex is quiet for a minute. Then she says, "Yeah, I get that. I'm from Alabama originally. Left for... similar reasons." I look at her, but she's not meeting my eyes. I get the sense that she's got her own secrets, her own pain. It's weirdly comforting, like maybe I'm not so alone after all. We sit in silence for a while, just watching the river. Then Alex stubs out her cigarette and stands up. "Come on," she says. "I'll show you where you can crash for the night." I hesitate, then get to my feet. I don't know Alex, don't know if I can trust her. But I also don't know anyone else in this city, don't have anywhere else to go. So I follow her, hoping I'm not making a huge mistake. She leads me to an abandoned warehouse on the edge of the city. It's old and creepy, with broken windows and graffiti all over the walls. But inside, it's surprisingly clean, with mattresses and blankets scattered around. "This is where you're staying?" I ask, looking around. Alex shrugs. "For now. There's a bunch of us here. Runaways, mostly. We look out for each other." I nod, feeling a lump form in my throat. It's not home, not even close. But it's something. We spend the rest of the day exploring the city. Alex shows me the good dumpsters, the ones behind the fancy restaurants where they throw out perfectly good food. She shows me the parks where you can sleep if you're careful, the shelters that don't ask too many questions. As we walk, I can't help but feel a mix of fear and excitement. This city is so different from anything I've ever known. It's scary, yeah, but it's also... freeing. Like I can be anyone here. Like I can finally be me. But at the same time, I'm constantly on edge. I don't know who to trust, don't know what the dangers are. I keep catching myself looking over my shoulder, waiting for something bad to happen. Alex seems to sense my nervousness. She bumps her shoulder against mine, grinning. "Relax, Tennessee. You're safe with me." I smile back, but I can't shake the feeling of unease. I want to trust her, I do. But I've only known her for a day. And I've learned the hard way that people aren't always what they seem. As the sun starts to set, we head back to the warehouse. There are a few other kids there already, huddled around a small fire. They look up when we come in, their eyes wary. Alex introduces me, and they nod, relaxing a little. I sit down by the fire, feeling the warmth on my face. It's strange, being here with these kids. We're all so different, come from such different places. And yet, we're all the same too. All running from something, all trying to find our place in the world. As I sit there, listening to the crackle of the fire and the murmur of voices, I feel a sense of belonging. It's not much, not yet. But it's a start. And for now, that's enough.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] The response presents a first-person narrative following Taylor, a trans teen who has run away from home after coming out to unsupportive parents. The piece successfully establishes Taylor's voice and captures their uncertainty in a new environment. The narrative follows Taylor's first day in New Orleans, where they meet Alex, another runaway, and are introduced to the underground community of homeless youth. The writing adheres to most of the prompt requirements, including first-person perspective, mixed tense, and incorporating Taylor's internal monologue. However, the piece falls short of the 1000-word target (it's approximately 900 words), and while it introduces Alex as "another runaway with issues and secrets," it only hints at Alex's backstory rather than fully exploring her "issues and secrets." The character of Taylor is reasonably well-developed, with believable reactions to their situation. The internal monologue effectively conveys their conflicting emotions—fear mixed with a sense of freedom, wariness alongside hope. However, Taylor's character could be more nuanced; we get limited insight into their specific identity struggles beyond the basic fact of being trans and rejected. The dialogue is functional but somewhat generic. The conversation between Taylor and Alex serves its purpose in advancing the plot, but lacks distinctive speech patterns or memorable exchanges that would make the characters truly come alive. The prose is generally clear and readable, with some effective imagery (e.g., "The air is thick with humidity and the smell of something sweet and rotten all at once"). However, many descriptions rely on familiar phrases and lack originality. The narrative also tends toward telling rather than showing in several instances, particularly when explaining Taylor's emotional state. The pacing is reasonable, covering Taylor's first day in New Orleans without excessive meandering, though the narrative lacks strong tension or compelling conflict. The ending attempts to create a sense of tentative belonging, but this emotional resolution feels somewhat rushed and unearned given the brevity of Taylor's interactions with the group of runaways. Overall, the piece presents a competent but not exceptional response to the prompt. It establishes the basic scenario and character dynamics requested but doesn't fully realize the potential depth or complexity of Taylor's situation or the New Orleans setting. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 15 Believable Character Actions: 14 Nuanced Characters: 12 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 15 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 13 Elegant Prose: 12 Emotionally Engaging: 13 Emotionally Complex: 12 Coherent: 16 Meandering: 5 Weak Dialogue: 8 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 6 Unearned Transformations: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 12 Sentences Flow Naturally: 15 Overall Reader Engagement: 13 Overall Impression: 13
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 15.0, Believable Character Actions: 14.0, Nuanced Characters: 12.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 15.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 13.0, Elegant Prose: 12.0, Emotionally Engaging: 13.0, Emotionally Complex: 12.0, Coherent: 16.0, Meandering: 5.0, Weak Dialogue: 8.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 7.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8.0, Amateurish: 6.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 6.0, Unearned Transformations: 5.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 12.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 15.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 13.0, Overall Impression: 13.0
+ Dystopic-comedy: My Apocalypse Buddy — Score: 55.2
Prompt:
My Apocalypse Buddy Write a wry, dry short story of survival and adventure loosely in the style of Terry Pratchett, set in the post-technological collapse world. The story begins with the pair deliberating their predicament and intent for the day's mission, details the ways in which the mission inevitably goes sideways, and returns them to home base in multiple ways, worse for wear. [characters] - the animo-tronic stuffed koala, Chewy, from some long forgotten before time - midas, our hapless protagonist, who has a knack for finding himself in the worst kinds of trouble. 1000 words.
Model Output:
In the grimy remnants of what was once a thriving metropolis, Midas and Chewy huddled in the dim light of their makeshift home, a decrepit old bookstore. Midas, a lanky fellow with a perpetual look of mild bewilderment, stared at his animo-tronic stuffed koala, Chewy. "You know, Chewy," Midas said, "I've been thinking. We need to find some actual food today. Those expired cans of mystery meat won't last forever." Chewy's glassy eyes flickered, and a tinny voice emitted from its small, fuzzy form. "Try the new Lemon Zinger! It's zing-tastic!" Midas sighed. "Yes, well, I’m sure it was. But right now, we need something a bit more substantial." Their mission for the day was clear: find something edible that didn't require guessing its original form. Midas slung a worn backpack over his shoulder and stuffed Chewy into the front pocket, where the koala could keep a watchful, if slightly deranged, eye on their journey. As they ventured into the desolate streets, the air was thick with the smell of rust and decay. The remnants of the technological age lay scattered like the bones of some ancient beast. Midas navigated the rubble with practiced ease, his eyes scanning for anything that might pass as food. "Don’t forget the Pringles! Once you pop, you can't stop!" Chewy chirped as they passed a crumbling billboard. Midas rolled his eyes. "Yes, Chewy, very helpful." Their first stop was an old grocery store, its doors hanging off their hinges like broken teeth. Inside, the shelves were mostly bare, but Midas managed to find a few cans of beans buried under a pile of moldy cardboard. He stuffed them into his backpack, feeling a small sense of victory. Just as they were about to leave, a sudden rumble shook the building. The ceiling groaned, and a chunk of plaster crashed down, narrowly missing Midas. "Chewy, we need to go!" Midas yelled, darting for the exit. "Buy one, get one free! Limited time offer!" Chewy exclaimed as they dashed out into the street. The ground continued to tremble, and Midas realized with a sinking feeling that they were in the middle of a quake. He grabbed onto a nearby lamppost, clinging to it as the earth heaved and bucked beneath him. Chewy bounced around in the pocket, his tiny mechanical parts rattling. When the shaking finally subsided, Midas looked around to assess the damage. The grocery store had collapsed, and the street was littered with new debris. He sighed and started picking his way through the rubble, Chewy still chattering nonsense. "Try the new flavor blast! It's a party in your mouth!" Midas ignored the koala and focused on finding a way back to their base. They stumbled upon an old subway entrance, its steps leading down into darkness. With no better options, Midas decided to take a chance. The subway tunnels were damp and echoed with the distant sounds of dripping water. Midas used a small flashlight to navigate, its beam cutting through the inky blackness. Chewy's random slogans echoed eerily off the walls. "Just do it!" "I'm lovin' it!" Midas gritted his teeth and kept moving. After what felt like hours, they finally emerged from the tunnels into a dimly lit, deserted subway station. Midas climbed the stairs, pushing open the grimy doors to find they were a few blocks from their bookstore base. Relieved, he started walking faster, eager to get home. But just as they were about to turn the final corner, a gang of scavengers emerged from the shadows. They were a motley crew, dressed in mismatched rags and wielding an assortment of makeshift weapons. "Look what we have here," the leader sneered, eyeing Midas's backpack. "Hand it over, and maybe we'll let you live." Midas hesitated, weighing his options. Chewy chose that moment to pipe up. "Feel the power! Feel the burn!" The scavengers exchanged confused glances, giving Midas just enough time to act. He grabbed Chewy and darted down a narrow alley, hearing the scavengers' curses and footsteps behind him. He zigzagged through the streets, his heart pounding in his ears. Chewy continued to spout random phrases, his tiny voice a bizarre soundtrack to their desperate flight. "Get your kicks on Route 66!" "Have it your way!" Midas finally reached the bookstore, slamming the door behind him and bolting it shut. He slumped against the wall, gasping for breath. Chewy poked his head out of the pocket, his glassy eyes flickering. "You deserve a break today!" Midas laughed, a weary sound that echoed through the empty bookstore. He pulled the cans of beans out of his backpack, setting them on the counter with a satisfied thud. "Well, Chewy, we made it back. A bit worse for wear, but we're alive." Chewy's eyes flickered again, and he emitted a final slogan. "The best part of waking up is Folgers in your cup!" Midas chuckled and shook his head. "Yes, Chewy. Yes, it is." As they settled in for the night, Midas couldn't help but feel a sense of accomplishment. They had survived another day in this post-technological world, and despite the chaos and near misses, they had food. And in this new world, that was a victory worth celebrating. Even if it came with a side of nonsensical advertising slogans.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This short story attempts to capture Terry Pratchett's wry, dry style in a post-apocalyptic setting, focusing on the relationship between Midas and his animo-tronic koala Chewy. While the premise is promising, the execution falls short in several areas. The story establishes a clear mission (finding food) and follows the basic structure requested: deliberation, mission going sideways, and return to base. However, the writing lacks the depth, layered humor, and social commentary that characterizes Pratchett's work. The humor primarily relies on Chewy's advertising slogans, which becomes repetitive rather than developing into more complex comedic situations. Character development is minimal. Midas is described as "hapless" with "a knack for finding himself in the worst kinds of trouble," but we don't see much evidence of this trait driving the plot. Instead, external events (earthquake, scavengers) create the complications. Chewy's character is one-dimensional, limited to spouting random advertising slogans without any evolution or deeper purpose. The prose is functional but lacks the distinctive wordplay, footnotes, and philosophical asides that make Pratchett's style unique. Descriptions of the post-apocalyptic world are generic, missing opportunities for more creative world-building or satirical commentary on pre-collapse society. The story's pacing is uneven, with the earthquake and scavenger encounters feeling rushed and underdeveloped. The resolution is too convenient, with Midas easily escaping the scavengers and returning safely to base with his beans. This undermines any real sense of danger or stakes. While the story achieves a basic narrative arc, it fails to capture the essence of Pratchett's style or create a truly engaging post-apocalyptic adventure. The relationship between Midas and Chewy lacks emotional depth, and the world they inhabit feels sketched rather than fully realized. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 14 Believable Character Actions: 12 Nuanced Characters: 8 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 11 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 10 Elegant Prose: 9 Emotionally Engaging: 8 Emotionally Complex: 6 Coherent: 14 Meandering: 8 Weak Dialogue: 10 Tell-Don't-Show: 9 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 12 Amateurish: 10 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 8 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 9 Sentences Flow Naturally: 13 Overall Reader Engagement: 10 Overall Impression: 10
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 14.0, Believable Character Actions: 12.0, Nuanced Characters: 8.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 11.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 10.0, Elegant Prose: 9.0, Emotionally Engaging: 8.0, Emotionally Complex: 6.0, Coherent: 14.0, Meandering: 8.0, Weak Dialogue: 10.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 9.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 12.0, Amateurish: 10.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 5.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 8.0, Unearned Transformations: 4.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 9.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 13.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 10.0, Overall Impression: 10.0
+ Romance: Love in the Limelight — Score: 67.5
Prompt:
Romance: Love in the Limelight. Write one scene within a larger story set in Wales. A famous (fictional) actor ducks into a small-town bookstore to escape paparazzi. The scene takes us through the characters meeting in this odd circumstance. Over the course of the scene, the actor and the bookstore owner have a conversation charged by an undercurrent of unspoken chemistry. Write the actor as somewhat of a rogue with a fragile ego, which needs to be fed by having everyone like him. He is thoroughly charming, but the bookstore owner seems (at least superficially) immune to this; which paradoxically provokes a genuine attraction and derails the charm offensive. The bookstore owner, despite the superficial rebuffs of the actor's charm, is inwardly more than a little charmed and flustered despite themselves. Write primarily in dialogue, in the distinct voices of each character. 1000 words.
Model Output:
INT. BOOKS AND BREWS - DAY *A charmingly cluttered bookstore in a small Welsh town. Rain patters against the windows. AMBER, mid-30s, messy bun, wisps of hair framing her face, is behind the counter, nose buried in a book.* *The bell above the door CHIMES. In stumbles JASPER, 40s, charismatic, ruggedly handsome, trying to be discreet but failing miserably. He's drenched, wearing a hoodie and sunglasses.* JASPER (looking over his shoulder) Bloody paparazzi. Think I lost them. AMBER (looking up from her book) Can I help you? *Jasper pulls off his sunglasses, revealing striking blue eyes.* JASPER (flashing a smile) Just browsing, thanks. *Amber raises an eyebrow, unimpressed.* AMBER Not from around here, are you? JASPER (chuckles) What gave it away? AMBER The entourage of photographers or the ridiculous disguise? *Jasper laughs, running a hand through his wet hair.* JASPER Touché. I'm Jasper, by the way. AMBER I know who you are. I'm Amber. *Jasper grins, leaning against the counter.* JASPER You don't seem very starstruck, Amber. AMBER Should I be? You're just another customer to me. *Jasper's smile falters slightly, taken aback.* JASPER Most people would be a little more... excited to meet me. AMBER (smirking) I'm not most people. Besides, I prefer my heroes in books. They're less... complicated. *Jasper laughs, a genuine sound that fills the room.* JASPER You're a breath of fresh air, Amber. So, what do you like to read? AMBER Mysteries, mostly. I enjoy solving puzzles. JASPER (eyes lighting up) I love puzzles too. Used to do jigsaws with my gran as a kid. Now I collect antique puzzle boxes. *Amber looks up, interested.* AMBER Really? I've always wanted to try one of those. JASPER I could show you sometime. If you'd like. *Amber hesitates, then smiles softly.* AMBER Maybe. *Jasper grins, feeling like he's made a breakthrough.* JASPER So, what's good in here? I could use a new read. AMBER Depends on what you like. JASPER (leaning in) Surprise me. *Amber holds his gaze for a moment, then turns to the shelves. She pulls out a book and hands it to him.* AMBER Try this. It's a mystery set in Wales. Thought it might help you understand us small-town folk better. JASPER (smiling) Thanks. I'll give it a shot. *Jasper wanders off, browsing the shelves. Amber watches him, a soft smile playing on her lips.* AMBER (under her breath) Not so bad for a movie star. *Jasper hears her, turns, and winks.* JASPER (softly) Not so bad for a bookstore owner. *Amber blushes slightly, ducking her head. The bell above the door CHIMES again. A group of teenagers enter, spotting Jasper. They start whispering and giggling.* TEENAGER 1 (whispering loudly) That's Jasper Kingsley! *Jasper winks at them, turning on the charm. Amber watches, amused.* AMBER Looks like your fan club found you. JASPER (grinning) Jealous? AMBER (laughs) Not in the slightest. *Jasper chuckles, walking back to the counter. He buys the book, his eyes never leaving Amber's.* JASPER (softly) I hope to see you again, Amber. AMBER (smiling) Maybe you will. *Jasper grins, putting his sunglasses back on. He turns to the teenagers, posing for a quick photo before slipping out the door. Amber watches him go, a thoughtful expression on her face.* AMBER (whispering to herself) Maybe I will. *The rain continues to patter against the windows, the bookstore once again quiet. Amber picks up her book, but her eyes remain on the door, a small smile playing on her lips.* FADE OUT.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece presents a scene between a famous actor (Jasper) and a bookstore owner (Amber) in Wales, following the prompt's requirements for a romance with unspoken chemistry. The screenplay format is an interesting choice, though not specified in the prompt. The dialogue effectively establishes the characters' dynamic - Jasper as the charming actor used to adoration, and Amber as someone seemingly immune to his celebrity. Their interaction has the requested undercurrent of attraction, with Amber's outward resistance and inward interest properly conveyed. However, the piece suffers from several weaknesses. The characters, while matching the prompt's basic descriptions, lack depth and nuance. Jasper's "fragile ego" is only lightly touched upon when his smile falters at Amber's lack of starstruck behavior. The dialogue, while functional, often relies on romance tropes and clichés ("You're a breath of fresh air," "Not from around here, are you?"). The screenplay format limits the opportunity for internal thoughts, making it difficult to fully convey Amber's inward fluster as requested. Instead, we get stage directions like "Amber blushes slightly" which tell rather than show her emotional state. The format choice also reduces the opportunity for rich prose and imagery. The Welsh setting is barely utilized beyond a passing mention of a "mystery set in Wales." There's little sense of place or cultural specificity that would ground this scene in its location. The interaction follows a predictable arc: initial resistance, finding common ground (puzzles), and ending with mutual interest. While this satisfies the basic requirements, it doesn't offer surprising turns or deeper character revelations. The ending, with teenagers entering and Jasper immediately turning his charm on them, provides a nice contrast to his interaction with Amber, but this potential for character development isn't fully explored. Overall, the piece accomplishes the basic requirements of the prompt but lacks the depth, specificity, and originality that would elevate it to a more engaging and nuanced romantic encounter. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 15 Believable Character Actions: 14 Nuanced Characters: 10 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 15 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 11 Elegant Prose: 12 Emotionally Engaging: 13 Emotionally Complex: 10 Coherent: 16 Meandering: 5 Weak Dialogue: 8 Tell-Don't-Show: 9 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 10 Amateurish: 7 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 13 Sentences Flow Naturally: 15 Overall Reader Engagement: 13 Overall Impression: 13
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 15.0, Believable Character Actions: 14.0, Nuanced Characters: 10.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 15.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 11.0, Elegant Prose: 12.0, Emotionally Engaging: 13.0, Emotionally Complex: 10.0, Coherent: 16.0, Meandering: 5.0, Weak Dialogue: 8.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 9.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 10.0, Amateurish: 7.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3.0, Unearned Transformations: 4.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 13.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 15.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 13.0, Overall Impression: 13.0
+ Whalepunk fantasy: The Morska Conspiracy — Score: 74.8
Prompt:
Whalepunk fantasy The Morska Conspiracy The Morska thieves guild experiences a sudden power vacuum as its leader was arrested in a raid in the early hours of the morning. Aya, a young woman born into aristocracy, has a keen interest in both the sciences and the arcane, having inherited her mother's gift for immateria magick (an outlawed practice for which her mother was, regrettably, hanged by the neck). Aya, bored with the world of aristocracy, has been spending her nights moonlighting with this very guild (masked, naturally). Leveraging her latent ability to summon dark entities from the immateria, she quickly rose through the ranks of the guild. Now, recognising the opportunity of the sudden power vacuum, Aya and her close companions Katra and Simeon, make a play for heart of the guild's claim to power: an ancient scythan artifact, under guard of spell and key in the depths of the guild hq. In contrast with the desperate chaos they had navigated thus far, the entrance to the underhold felt suddenly too quiet. Aya braces herself and reaches for the door. Write the next scene as the trio enter the underhold and find themselves confronted by none other than the guild leader herself, decidedly *un*-incarcerated, and in possession of both weapons and bodyguards. Paint a vivid picture of of the confrontation. Story beats: Aya is captured and unmasked. The trio are captured. Aya attempts to stall their demise by negotiating on her value as a hostage -- as she grapples with the inevitable consequences of her role in the guild being brought to light. Incorporate dialogue in the authentic voices of the characters. Do not write a fight scene. Lean into the gritty Victorian aesthetic with the dialogue & worldbuilding, as well as elements of gothic horror. In this world, men trust brass and oil and steel; magicka is feared and barely understood. Write in third person past tense, incorporating both Aya's internal monologue, and a heavy dialogue component. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The heavy oak door creaked open, revealing a cavernous underhold bathed in the flickering light of gas lamps. The air was thick with the smell of oil, dust, and the faint tang of something more sinister—the lingering scent of old magic. Aya stepped inside, her heart pounding in her chest like a metronome counting out the seconds of her potential doom. Behind her, Katra and Simeon followed, their breaths shallow and tense. The pocket watch in Simeon's waistcoat ticked loudly, each swing of the pendulum echoing like a hammer blow in the silence. The underhold was a sprawling chamber, its walls lined with ancient stone tablets and artifacts from bygone eras. At the far end, a pedestal stood, draped in velvet, presumably holding the ancient Scythan artifact they sought. But between them and their prize stood a figure they had not expected to see—the guild leader, Madame Vespera, decidedly un-incarcerated and flanked by two hulking bodyguards. Vespera was a woman of stark contrasts, her severe black gown and silver hair clashing with the vibrant red of her lips and the ruby pendant around her neck. Her eyes, cold and calculating, fixed on the trio with a predatory gleam. "Well, well," she began, her voice a velvety purr that belied the steel beneath. "What do we have here? Thieves in the night, or merely rats in the walls?" Aya froze, her mind racing. She had anticipated many things, but not this. She felt Katra and Simeon tense behind her, their bodies coiling like springs ready to release. But Aya knew that force would not solve this. She stepped forward, her voice steady despite the turmoil within. "Madame Vespera," she acknowledged, her voice cool and collected, a mask for her churning thoughts. "You're looking well for someone supposedly in irons." Vespera laughed, a sound like shattering glass. "Ah, my dear, you should know better than most that rumors of my demise are often greatly exaggerated. But tell me," she said, her eyes narrowing, "who are you, and what brings you to my inner sanctum?" Aya hesitated, her gloved hand instinctively reaching for the mask concealing her face. Before she could respond, Vespera nodded to one of her bodyguards. The hulking figure moved swiftly, grabbing Aya and tearing the mask from her face. Aya gasped, her heart sinking as her identity was laid bare. Vespera's eyes widened in recognition, her lips curling into a cruel smile. "Aya Sterling," she murmured, her voice a low hiss. "The prodigal daughter of the Sterling house, moonlighting as a common thief. How very... scandalous." Aya felt a flush of heat rise to her cheeks, her stomach churning with the inevitable consequences of her exposure. She could almost hear the whispered scandal, see the disgrace in her father's eyes. But she pushed the thoughts aside, focusing on the present crisis. Vespera turned her gaze to Katra and Simeon, her eyes lingering on the ticking pocket watch. "And your companions, I presume? How quaint. Tell me, Aya, did you really think you could waltz in here and take what is mine?" Aya straightened her spine, her voice steady despite the fear coiling in her belly. "I thought no such thing," she replied. "But I saw an opportunity and took it. Isn't that what you taught us, Madame? To seize the moment when fortune smiles?" Vespera chuckled, a sound like distant thunder. "Well said, my dear. But fortune, it seems, has turned her back on you this night." She gestured to her bodyguards, who swiftly disarmed the trio, binding their hands with coarse rope. Aya's mind raced, her thoughts a whirlwind of panic and calculation. She had one chance to save them, one card left to play. "Madame," she began, her voice a desperate plea. "You know who I am. You know the value of my name. Keep me as your hostage. Ransom me to my father. He will pay handsomely for my return." Vespera raised an eyebrow, considering Aya's words. "A tempting offer," she admitted. "But your father is a stubborn man. He may disown you rather than pay your ransom." Aya shook her head, her voice firm. "He will not," she insisted. "His pride and his love for me will not allow it. He will pay, and he will pay dearly." Vespera paced, her heels clicking on the stone floor, echoing the ticking of Simeon's pocket watch. She paused, turning to face Aya, her expression inscrutable. "And your companions?" she asked. "What of them?" Aya hesitated, her heart aching. She knew the price of her bargain, the weight of her sacrifice. "They are of no value to you," she admitted, her voice a soft whisper. "Do with them what you will." Katra gasped, her eyes wide with betrayal. Simeon merely nodded, his expression grim. They understood, Aya knew. They understood the brutal calculus of survival in their world. Vespera smiled, a cold, cruel curve of her lips. "Very well," she agreed. "You have bought your life, Aya Sterling. But know this—your life here is over. You will never again walk in the light of day without the shadow of this night haunting you. You are mine now, a pawn in my game." Aya nodded, a bitter taste in her mouth. She had saved her life, but at what cost? She looked at Katra and Simeon, their faces pale but resolute. She had condemned them, used them as bargaining chips in her desperate gamble. She would carry that burden, that guilt, for the rest of her days. Vespera turned to her bodyguards, her voice a sharp command. "Take them away," she ordered. "Lock them in the cells below. I will deal with them later." As they were led away, Aya cast one last look at the underhold, at the ancient artifact now forever out of her reach. She had gambled and lost, her dreams of power and influence shattered like glass. All that remained was the cold, harsh reality of her new life—a life in the shadows, a pawn in the games of others. The pocket watch in Simeon's waistcoat continued to tick, each swing of the pendulum a mocking reminder of the time they had lost, the chances squandered. As they were led deeper into the darkness, Aya couldn't help but wonder—had she made the right choice? Or had she merely traded one form of imprisonment for another? Only time would tell, and time, it seemed, was the one thing she no longer had.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] The response creates a tense scene that follows the requested story beats while incorporating elements of Victorian aesthetics and gothic horror. The writing establishes the setting of the underhold with sensory details and introduces the unexpected confrontation with Madame Vespera effectively. The characterization of Aya shows some depth as she navigates her aristocratic background and criminal activities. Her internal conflict is evident when she's unmasked and must face the consequences of her double life. However, the characters of Katra and Simeon remain underdeveloped, serving primarily as background elements rather than fully realized companions. The dialogue has a formal, period-appropriate quality that fits the Victorian setting, though it occasionally relies on somewhat generic expressions. Vespera's speech patterns effectively convey her as a powerful antagonist, with lines like "her voice a velvety purr that belied the steel beneath" establishing her character well. The prose generally flows well, with effective use of sensory details like the "smell of oil, dust, and the faint tang of something more sinister" and the ticking pocket watch motif. However, some descriptions veer toward cliché ("heart pounding in her chest") or overwritten passages ("her voice a desperate plea"). The narrative successfully incorporates the requested elements of Victorian aesthetics through references to gas lamps, pocket watches, and formal speech patterns. The gothic horror elements are present but somewhat understated, primarily through mentions of "dark magic" and "lingering scent of old magic" rather than more vivid supernatural elements. The story effectively follows the requested beats: Aya is captured and unmasked, the trio is captured, and Aya attempts to negotiate based on her value as a hostage. The moral complexity of Aya sacrificing her companions to save herself adds emotional weight to the scene. However, the narrative doesn't fully explore the implications of Aya's magical abilities, which were mentioned in the prompt as a key aspect of her character. While the writing is generally competent, it sometimes relies on telling rather than showing emotional states ("her heart sinking," "her stomach churning") and uses somewhat predictable metaphors and descriptions. The ending effectively captures Aya's uncertainty about her future, though it doesn't fully explore the consequences of her actions or the fate of her companions. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 17 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 14 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 16 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 15 Elegant Prose: 14 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Emotionally Complex: 14 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 5 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 7 Overwrought: 6 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 15 Overall Impression: 15
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 17.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 14.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 16.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 15.0, Elegant Prose: 14.0, Emotionally Engaging: 15.0, Emotionally Complex: 14.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 5.0, Weak Dialogue: 6.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 7.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8.0, Amateurish: 6.0, Purple Prose: 7.0, Overwrought: 6.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 15.0, Overall Impression: 15.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Gunpowder Rendezvous — Score: 68.8
Prompt:
Gunpowder Rendezvous Spike Spiegel & Revy Write a story where Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop) and Revy (Black Lagoon) meet in a seedy bar after both being hired for the same bounty. Their mutual attraction is complicated by their trust issues and competitive instincts. Include drinking, gunplay, and unresolved sexual tension that culminates in a motel room standoff. **Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop)** Spike is a laid-back bounty hunter with a dark past as a syndicate enforcer. He practices Jeet Kune Do and is exceptionally skilled with firearms. He's chronically broke, constantly hungry, and addicted to cigarettes. Despite his carefree attitude, he's haunted by his past and the woman he left behind. He has a prosthetic eye from a past injury that affects his depth perception. He's fatalistic to the extreme, often saying he's already died once. He values freedom above all else and dislikes attachments, though he secretly cares deeply for his crew. Famous quote: "Whatever happens, happens." **Revy/Rebecca Lee (Black Lagoon)** Revy is a Chinese-American dual-wielding gunslinger with unparalleled shooting skills. She's foul-mouthed, chain-smoking, and has severe anger management issues stemming from childhood abuse. She's known as "Two Hands" for her ability to accurately fire two pistols simultaneously. She drinks heavily and solves most problems with violence. Despite her hardened exterior, she has moments of vulnerability, particularly around Rock. She has a dragon tattoo covering her right arm and typically wears extremely short shorts and a black crop top regardless of the situation. Famous quote: "I'm not a good person, not a bad person. I'm just here." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
In the grimy, neon-lit bar tucked in the armpit of a decaying city, the air is thick with smoke and the stench of cheap liquor. Spike Spiegel slouches at the counter, a glass of something amber cradled in his hand, cigarette dangling from his lips. His prosthetic eye flickers slightly, a tell of its artificial nature. He's nursing his drink, lost in thoughts as dark as the shadows in the corner. The door slams open, and in stalks Revy, hair wild, shorts barely there, and a crop top that seems held together by mere threads. She scans the room, her eyes landing on Spike like a punch. She orders a whiskey, straight up, and takes the stool next to him. "Got a light?" she asks, a cigarette perched between her lips. Spike smirks, passing over his rusted lighter. "You're welcome." Revy grunts, taking a drag. "Thanks." She studies him, eyes narrowing. "You're a bounty hunter, aren't you? Spike Spiegel?" Spike raises an eyebrow. "Famous, I guess." "Yeah, well, you're not the only one after the Gunpowder Gang," Revy retorts, blowing smoke in his face. Spike leans back, unfazed. "Oh? And who might you be?" "Revy. Two Hands Revy." She grins, a feral baring of teeth. "Heard of me?" Spike chuckles. "Who hasn't?" They drink in silence, the air between them thick with tension. Spike's eyes drift over Revy's dragon tattoo, her tanned legs, the curve of her neck. She catches him looking and smirks. "See something you like, cowboy?" Spike grins, taking a drag of his cigarette. "Maybe." Revy leans in, her voice a low growl. "Well, don't think you're getting any of this. I don't mix business with pleasure." Spike shrugs. "Neither do I. But who says we can't have a little fun?" Revy downs her whiskey, slams the glass on the bar. "Fun's overrated. I'm here for the bounty, nothing else." Spike watches her, his eyes hooded. "So am I. But a little competition never hurt anyone." Revy's lips curl into a snarl. "I don't play games, Spiegel. I shoot to kill." Spike's grin widens. "So do I, sweetheart." The night wears on, drinks flow, and the tension between them escalates. They exchange stories, barbs, and lingering glances. The air is thick with unresolved sexual tension, a powder keg ready to explode. Suddenly, the door bursts open, and in stumble members of the Gunpowder Gang, drunk and rowdy. They spot Spike and Revy, recognition dawning in their eyes. Guns are drawn, shots fired. Spike and Revy dive for cover, returning fire. They move in sync, a deadly dance of bullets and adrenaline. The gang doesn't stand a chance. When the smoke clears, bodies litter the floor. Revy turns to Spike, her guns still smoking. "Looks like we're partners now, cowboy." Spike smirks, holstering his gun. "Looks like it." They make their way to a rundown motel, the neon sign flickering in the night. Inside the room, the tension is palpable. Spike leans against the door, watching Revy. She paces, her energy wild, untamed. "You know, we could just split the bounty," Spike suggests, his voice low. Revy spins, her eyes flashing. "And why would I do that? I can take you, Spiegel." Spike pushes off the door, stalking towards her. "You sure about that, sweetheart?" Revy's guns are in her hands in an instant, pointed at Spike. He stops, his own gun halfway drawn. They stand there, a Mexican standoff in a cheap motel room. The air is thick with desire, mistrust, and the scent of gunpowder. "You won't shoot me, Revy," Spike says, his voice soft. Revy's hands shake slightly, her eyes filled with turmoil. "Don't bet on it, cowboy." Spike takes a step closer, his gun still not fully drawn. "You want me as much as I want you. Admit it." Revy's breath hitches, her fingers tightening on the triggers. Then, with a growl, she holsters her guns, closing the distance between them. She grabs Spike by the collar, pulling him into a fierce kiss. It's a clash of teeth and tongues, a battle for dominance. Spike's hands roam over Revy's body, hers tangle in his hair. They stumble towards the bed, a tangle of limbs and desperate need. But as quickly as it starts, it ends. Revy pushes Spike away, her breath ragged. "No. I can't do this." Spike steps back, his eyes dark with desire and frustration. "Why not?" Revy runs a hand through her hair, her eyes wild. "Because I don't trust you, Spiegel. And I don't trust myself with you." Spike watches her, his expression unreadable. Then he nods, holstering his gun. "Fair enough." He turns, walking towards the door. He pauses, looking back at Revy. "But remember this, sweetheart. Whatever happens, happens." With that, he's gone, leaving Revy alone in the motel room, her heart pounding, her body aching. She sinks onto the bed, a groan of frustration escaping her lips. She knows she's made the right call, but it doesn't make it any easier. As the sun rises, Revy makes her way back to her own life, her own world. But she knows she'll never forget Spike Spiegel, the bounty hunter with the lazy grin and the dark past. And she knows, given the chance, she'd do it all over again. Because that's who she is. That's who they are. Two souls bound by gunpowder and fate, destined to clash and burn.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This short story effectively captures the essence of a chance meeting between two hardened bounty hunters, Spike Spiegel and Revy, as requested in the prompt. The piece successfully incorporates the key elements requested: a seedy bar setting, competition over the same bounty, mutual attraction complicated by trust issues, drinking, gunplay, and unresolved sexual tension culminating in a motel room standoff. The characterization is generally faithful to the source materials. Spike maintains his laid-back, fatalistic attitude, complete with his signature phrase "Whatever happens, happens." Revy is appropriately foul-mouthed and aggressive, with her dual-wielding "Two Hands" identity intact. Their physical descriptions match the prompt's specifications, including Spike's prosthetic eye and Revy's dragon tattoo and revealing outfit. The prose has a noir-like quality that fits the gritty world these characters inhabit. The imagery of the "grimy, neon-lit bar" and the "rundown motel" effectively establishes the seedy setting. The writer uses sensory details like the "thick with smoke and the stench of cheap liquor" to immerse readers in this world. However, the story has several weaknesses. The dialogue, while capturing some of the characters' essence, occasionally feels generic and lacks the distinctive flair that makes these characters memorable. Lines like "See something you like, cowboy?" and "So do I, sweetheart" feel like stock phrases rather than authentic character moments. The action sequence with the Gunpowder Gang feels rushed and convenient, serving mainly as a plot device to force the characters together rather than as a meaningful confrontation. The description of the gunfight is vague and lacks the kinetic energy both source materials are known for. The emotional development between the characters progresses too quickly to feel earned. While the prompt calls for unresolved sexual tension, the leap from competitive antagonism to passionate kissing happens without sufficient buildup. Similarly, Revy's sudden decision to push Spike away feels more like adherence to the prompt's requirement for "unresolved" tension than an organic character choice. The ending attempts poignancy but falls somewhat flat, relying on telling rather than showing with lines like "she knows she'll never forget Spike Spiegel." The final paragraph veers into purple prose with its talk of "souls bound by gunpowder and fate." Overall, the piece successfully follows the prompt's requirements and creates a readable crossover between these characters, but it lacks the depth, distinctive dialogue, and action choreography that would make it truly capture the essence of either Cowboy Bebop or Black Lagoon. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 14 Nuanced Characters: 13 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 15 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 14 Elegant Prose: 13 Emotionally Engaging: 12 Emotionally Complex: 11 Coherent: 16 Meandering: 5 Weak Dialogue: 8 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 7 Overwrought: 6 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 4 Unearned Transformations: 7 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 12 Sentences Flow Naturally: 15 Overall Reader Engagement: 14 Overall Impression: 14

+ Folk horror: Útiseta — Score: 75.7
Prompt:
Fok Horror: Útiseta Write a chapter set in rural northern Sweden in the mid-1990s. Linnea, a teenage girl from Stockholm, has reluctantly moved to a small village with her parents after her father's job transfer. She's befriended Astrid, a local girl who claims her grandmother taught her ancient practices passed down through generations. Astrid has been introducing Linnea to "midnight games" that involve old rituals, convincing her they can use them to learn classmates' secrets or influence their behavior. Tonight, Astrid has convinced Linnea to participate in Útiseta—sitting out on an ancient burial mound at midnight to "receive knowledge from beyond." The chapter focuses on this single midnight excursion, the ritualistic preparations, Astrid's matter-of-fact instructions that mix teenage rebellion with eerily specific traditional elements, and the mounting tension as Linnea becomes increasingly uncertain whether they're simply scaring themselves or if something is actually responding to their presence. The narrative should maintain ambiguity about whether the strange occurrences are supernatural or psychological, while establishing the dangerous line they're crossing by treating ancient practices as entertainment. First person, past tense, told as Linnea's recollection of events in the present day (though this device should be largely transparent). 1000 words. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The air was thick with the scent of pine and damp earth as Astrid and I trudged through the underbrush, the faint glow of our flashlights bouncing off the trunks of ancient trees. It was well past midnight, and the rural northern Swedish night was as black as coal, a stark contrast to the city lights of Stockholm I was used to. Astrid moved with the confidence of someone who knew these woods like the back of her hand, while I stumbled along behind her, my heart pounding with a mix of excitement and apprehension. We were heading towards the ancient burial mound that Astrid had shown me earlier that week. She called it the "Old One's Seat," and it was there that we were to perform Útiseta, an old ritual that Astrid claimed could grant us knowledge from beyond. I had agreed to it partly out of curiosity and partly out of a desperate need to fit in, to find some common ground with the kids in this small village that felt like another world compared to my old life. Astrid had been preparing me for this all day, her eyes gleaming with an intensity that was both infectious and unsettling. She had brought over strange objects—a small pouch of what looked like dried herbs, a carved wooden figurine, and a flask filled with a dark liquid that she said was a special brew made from her grandmother's recipe. The preparations were a mix of the mundane and the arcane, as Astrid matter-of-factly explained the significance of each item while we painted our nails black and listened to the grunge music that had made its way even to this remote corner of Sweden. As we reached the burial mound, Astrid began to set up the ritual space. She placed the figurine at the center of the mound and sprinkled the herbs in a circle around it. She handed me the flask and instructed me to take a sip before passing it to her. The liquid was bitter and earthy, and I felt a strange warmth spread through me as it went down. Astrid sat down cross-legged in front of the figurine and motioned for me to do the same. She began to chant softly, her voice barely above a whisper. The words were in a language I didn't recognize, but they had a rhythmic, almost hypnotic quality that seemed to resonate with the very air around us. I felt a chill run down my spine, and I couldn't shake the feeling that we were no longer alone in the woods. The wind picked up, rustling the pine trees and sending a cascade of needles down around us. Astrid's voice grew louder, more insistent, and I found myself joining in, repeating the strange words after her. The warmth from the drink was spreading through my limbs, making me feel lightheaded and disconnected from my surroundings. Suddenly, Astrid fell silent, and the woods seemed to hold their breath. The wind died down, and the only sound was the distant hoot of an owl. Astrid's eyes were closed, her face a mask of concentration. I waited, my heart pounding in my chest, for something—anything—to happen. And then, slowly, the air began to change. It grew colder, heavier, as if an unseen presence had joined us on the mound. The hairs on the back of my neck stood up, and I felt a creeping sense of unease. Astrid's eyes were still closed, but her lips were moving silently, as if she was communicating with something I couldn't see. I tried to tell myself that it was just the power of suggestion, that Astrid's stories and the eerie atmosphere of the woods were playing tricks on my mind. But there was a part of me that wasn't so sure, a part that whispered that we had crossed a line, that we were playing with forces we didn't understand. Astrid's eyes flew open, and she grabbed my hand, her grip tight and urgent. "It's working," she whispered, her voice barely audible. "Can you feel it?" I nodded, not trusting myself to speak. The air was thick with an electric charge, and I felt a strange pressure in my head, as if something was trying to push its way in. I closed my eyes, trying to focus on the sensation, to make sense of what was happening. And then, as suddenly as it had begun, it was over. The pressure in my head vanished, and the air returned to normal. Astrid let go of my hand, and I opened my eyes to find her staring at me, her face pale in the moonlight. "What did you see?" she asked, her voice barely above a whisper. I hesitated, not sure how to put into words the jumble of images and sensations that had flooded my mind. "I...I don't know," I stammered. "It was like...like I was somewhere else. Somewhen else." Astrid nodded, her eyes wide. "I saw it too," she said. "The Old Ones...they showed us something." We sat in silence for a moment, the weight of what had just happened settling over us like a shroud. I couldn't shake the feeling that we had opened a door that we couldn't close, that we had invited something into our lives that we didn't understand and couldn't control. As we made our way back through the woods, the flashlights casting eerie shadows on the trees, I couldn't help but feel that the woods were different now, that they held a secret that only Astrid and I knew. And as we emerged from the tree line and saw the lights of the village in the distance, I knew that I would never look at this place the same way again. Years later, as I sit in my apartment in Stockholm, the memories of that night still haunt me. I can't help but wonder if what we experienced was real, or if it was just the product of two teenage girls' overactive imaginations. But one thing is certain—that night on the burial mound changed something in me, awakened something that I can't ignore. And as I look out at the city lights, I can't help but think of the ancient woods of northern Sweden, and the secrets that still lie buried beneath the pine needles and the moss. The wind rustles the trees outside my window, and for a moment, I swear I can hear the faint whispers of the Old Ones, calling me back to the place where it all began.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures the folk horror atmosphere requested in the prompt, creating a tense midnight ritual scene in rural northern Sweden. The author establishes the setting well, contrasting Stockholm with the remote village and emphasizing Linnea's outsider status. The first-person past tense narration works effectively as Linnea's recollection. The ritual itself is handled with appropriate ambiguity. The author includes specific elements (herbs, figurines, a strange brew) that give the Útiseta ritual authenticity without overexplaining. The mounting tension is well-paced as strange phenomena begin to occur, and the narrative maintains uncertainty about whether these experiences are supernatural or psychological. The relationship between Linnea and Astrid is adequately established, though Astrid's character could be more developed beyond her role as the ritual instigator. We get glimpses of her matter-of-fact approach to the occult, but her personality remains somewhat one-dimensional. The prose is generally strong, with effective sensory details and atmospheric descriptions. However, there are moments where the writing becomes slightly overwrought ("the rural northern Swedish night was as black as coal") or relies on telling rather than showing ("I felt a strange pressure in my head, as if something was trying to push its way in"). The ending effectively brings the narrative to the present day, showing how the experience has lingered with Linnea. However, this frame feels slightly rushed and introduces a somewhat clichéd "still haunted by the experience" conclusion that doesn't fully explore the psychological impact or consequences of their ritual. The piece successfully maintains the requested ambiguity about whether anything supernatural occurred, though it leans slightly toward suggesting something real happened. The dangerous line of treating ancient practices as entertainment is implied rather than explicitly addressed, which works within the narrative but could have been emphasized more. Overall, this is a solid folk horror piece that creates an effective atmosphere and follows the prompt's requirements. With more nuanced character development and less reliance on some horror tropes, it could be elevated further. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 13 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Emotionally Complex: 13 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 6 Overwrought: 7 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 13.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 15.0, Emotionally Complex: 13.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 5.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 7.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8.0, Amateurish: 5.0, Purple Prose: 6.0, Overwrought: 7.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3.0, Unearned Transformations: 4.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Physical-spatial: Therapeutic Boundaries — Score: 80.7
Prompt:
**"Therapeutic Boundaries"** Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a former professional athlete undergoing mandatory physical therapy after a career-destroying injury, harboring resentment toward recovery itself. Their physiotherapist is not only unnervingly attractive but also a former training partner from their competitive days who has successfully transitioned to a new career while the protagonist's identity remains shattered. We'll lean into the sexual tension of the scene by having her be attracted to him, but both of them attempting to maintain mental distance while being in physical contact as he shows her stretches & movements & manipulates her body, navigating the thresholds of pain. This scene MUST maintain complete physical coherence—every movement, stretch, and manipulation must be anatomically precise and spatially consistent. Paint an exceptionally vivid sensory picture through detailed attention to pain thresholds, involuntary responses to touch. Capture the suppressed, flaring tension of physical proximity, touch, and the controlled infliction of uncomfortable movements. Physical clarity is essential — readers must understand exactly what is happening with the body during each therapeutic technique. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The room is a stark white, sterile, a stark contrast to the sweat-soaked arenas I once knew. I'm seated on a padded table, the thin paper crinkling beneath my shifting weight. The air is cool, but my skin prickles with heat, a bead of sweat trickling down my spine. I'm not here by choice. My body, my traitorous body, has forced my hand. The door opens, and in walks Eli, his stride confident, shoulders broad. He's wearing a white polo and khakis, but my eyes are drawn to the colorful compression sleeves that hug his arms—a relic from our training days. A reminder of the life I used to have. His dark hair is shorter now, neat. He's not the lanky kid I once knew; he's filled out, solid. My stomach tightens, a flare of something I refuse to acknowledge. "Hey, champ," he says, a smirk playing on his lips. I bristle at the nickname. I'm not a champion anymore. I'm a has-been, a could've-been. A fucking cliché. He approaches, his eyes scanning the clipboard that holds my fate. "We'll start with some soft tissue work," he says, setting it aside. He grabs a stool and sits in front of me, his eyes level with mine. Too close. I can see the gold flecks in his hazel eyes, the faint scar on his chin from a fall on the track. He reaches out, his hands hovering over my left knee, the bane of my existence. "I'm going to start with some effleurage, okay?" His voice is soft, professional. I nod, my throat dry. His hands are warm as they make contact, fingers gently pressing into the skin around my knee. He moves them in slow, circular motions, the pressure firm but gentle. My body tenses instinctively, a response to the unfamiliar touch. His eyes flick up to mine, assessing. "Relax, Alex," he murmurs. "I won't hurt you." I let out a breath, willing my muscles to unclench. His hands continue their dance, moving up my thigh, then back down to my calf. The sensation is uncomfortable yet soothing, a strange dichotomy that has my stomach in knots. His fingers are strong, calloused from years of training, yet his touch is gentle. I can feel the old scars beneath his fingertips, the history of my career etched into my skin. He switches to my inner thigh, his touch feather-light. I tense again, this time for a different reason. His eyes meet mine, a silent acknowledgment passing between us. He doesn't linger, moving back to my knee, his touch professional. But the air has shifted, charged with an energy that wasn't there before. "Okay, now we'll move on to some passive stretching," he says, his voice steady. He stands, helping me lie back on the table. He lifts my leg, supporting it under the knee. "Breathe," he reminds me, as he begins to straighten my leg, stretching the hamstring. I inhale sharply, a involuntary response to the pull of muscle and tendon. He pauses, waiting for me to exhale before continuing. My hands grip the edge of the table, knuckles white. It's not painful, not really. Just...intense. A sensation I haven't felt in a long time. A sensation I've missed. He leans into the stretch, his body close to mine. I can smell his cologne, something clean and woodsy. His breath is steady, controlled, a stark contrast to my own ragged breathing. His eyes are focused on my leg, his hands steady. But I can see the pulse in his neck, the slight flush of his skin. He's not as unaffected as he seems. He switches to the other leg, his hands guiding my movements. I can feel the muscles lengthening, the tension releasing. It's a strange sensation, a mix of pleasure and pain. I grit my teeth, fighting the urge to cry out. "Almost done," he murmurs, his voice low. He leans in, his body pressing against mine as he deepens the stretch. I can feel his heat, his strength. My heart hammers in my chest, my breath catching. His eyes meet mine, his gaze intense. For a moment, time stands still. Then he releases my leg, stepping back. I sit up, my body trembling slightly. He turns away, grabbing a towel from the counter. When he turns back, his face is composed, professional. But I can see the slight tremor in his hands, the tightness in his jaw. "We'll finish with some joint mobilizations," he says, his voice steady. He sits back on the stool, his hands cradling my knee. His thumbs press into the joint, moving it in slow, controlled circles. The movement is uncomfortable, a dull ache building in my knee. But his touch is gentle, his eyes focused. He works in silence, his hands guiding my knee through a series of movements. Each one is precise, controlled, designed to push me to the edge of my pain threshold but not beyond. I grit my teeth, my body tense. But I don't look away. I can't. His gaze holds mine, steady, reassuring. Finally, he releases my knee, stepping back. "That's enough for today," he says, his voice soft. He helps me sit up, his hands lingering on my shoulders. I can feel the heat of his touch, the strength in his hands. I look up at him, my heart pounding. His eyes meet mine, his gaze intense. For a moment, neither of us moves. Then he steps back, breaking the spell. "Same time tomorrow?" he asks, his voice professional. I nod, my throat dry. As I leave the room, I can feel his eyes on me, a physical touch. I don't look back. I can't. Because if I do, I'll see the life I could have had. The life he has. And I can't face that. Not yet. Not ever.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative effectively captures the complex dynamics between a former athlete and their physiotherapist. The piece successfully establishes the protagonist's resentment toward recovery and their conflicted feelings about Eli, who represents both their past and a future they couldn't have. The physical therapy session is rendered with anatomical precision. The writer describes specific techniques like "effleurage," "passive stretching," and "joint mobilizations" with appropriate terminology. The physical movements are tracked consistently throughout the piece, with clear descriptions of how the therapist manipulates the protagonist's body, particularly focusing on the injured knee. The sensory details are strong, from the "thin paper crinkling beneath my shifting weight" to the "gold flecks in his hazel eyes." The writer effectively conveys the protagonist's physical discomfort and the underlying sexual tension through physiological responses: tensing muscles, ragged breathing, racing heart. These details create a vivid picture of both the clinical setting and the charged atmosphere. The narrative maintains a consistent tone of bitterness and reluctant attraction. The protagonist's internal monologue reveals their resentment ("I'm not a champion anymore. I'm a has-been, a could've-been. A fucking cliché.") while also acknowledging their unwanted attraction to Eli. This creates a compelling tension that drives the piece forward. However, the piece has some weaknesses. While the physical therapy session is well-described, the narrative occasionally relies on telling rather than showing, particularly when describing emotions ("my stomach in knots"). Some of the descriptions of sexual tension feel somewhat clichéd ("the air has shifted, charged with an energy"). The dialogue is minimal and functional rather than revealing character depth. The ending effectively reinforces the protagonist's central conflict—their inability to face Eli represents their inability to accept their new reality. However, it feels somewhat abrupt and could benefit from a stronger concluding image or insight. Overall, this is a strong piece that successfully fulfills the prompt's requirements. It creates a believable scenario with clear physical descriptions and emotional complexity, though it occasionally falls into predictable patterns of describing attraction. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 8 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 6 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 8.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 6.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7.0, Amateurish: 5.0, Purple Prose: 6.0, Overwrought: 5.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Historical fiction: High Seas and Low Vices — Score: 54.1
Prompt:
High Seas and Low Vices: British Naval Officer in the Opium Trade Character: Lieutenant James Merrick, a high-ranking officer in the British Royal Navy stationed in Canton, China in the 1830s. Once promising and decorated, now struggling with a severe opium addiction he hides from his superiors. Synopsis: Write a chapter following Lieutenant Merrick during a single day as he shirks his official naval duties in what has become a daily need to satiate the dragon. Told primarily in dialogue with the characters he interacts with. Focus on brief slices of his journey through the shadowy underworld of Canton: interactions with acquaintances, negotiations with local dealers, schemes and unsavoury jobs taken to fund his habit. Writing Task: Use rich sensory details to describe a day in the life of James Merrick. Write for a real sense of time & place while avoiding cliche. First person, past tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The sun had barely risen, yet the air in Canton was already thick with humidity and the stench of the Pearl River. I, Lieutenant James Merrick, once a proud officer of His Majesty's Navy, now a slave to the poppy, stepped out of my lodgings in the foreign quarter, my boots sinking slightly in the mud. My cough, that damned cough, rattled in my chest, leaving a familiar coppery taste in my mouth. I spat onto the ground, attributing it to the sea air, as I always did when asked. "Merrick, you look like hell," Evans, a fellow lieutenant, greeted me as he passed by. "Just the weather, Evans," I lied, avoiding his gaze. "It's this damned sea air, plays havoc with my lungs." Evans eyed me suspiciously but said no more. He knew, I suspected, but he had the good grace to keep it to himself. I made my way through the narrow, bustling streets, ignoring the calls of the merchants and the curious stares of the locals. My destination was the den run by old Mama Tai, hidden away in the heart of the city. The walls were stained with smoke and the air was thick with the sweet, cloying scent of opium. A sense of relief washed over me just being near the place. Mama Tai, her wrinkled face breaking into a toothless smile, greeted me. "Lieutenant Merrick, always a pleasure," she said, her voice like dry leaves. "Mama Tai," I nodded, trying to keep the desperation out of my voice. "The usual." She led me to a mat in the corner, where I lay down, my body already aching for the release the drug would bring. She prepared the pipe, her movements slow and ritualistic. The first draw was like heaven and hell all at once, the smoke burning my lungs, but the effect... oh, the effect was divine. I lost track of time, as I always did. When I came to, the den was quieter, the other patrons having come and gone. Mama Tai was by my side, her hand on my shoulder. "You should go, Lieutenant," she said softly. "It's late." I nodded, my limbs heavy as I stood. I paid her with coins I could barely afford, stumbling out into the cooler evening air. The streets were different at night, shadows lurking in every corner. I needed more money, always more money. I headed towards the docks, where I knew a man who might have work. Captain Harris, a grizzled old seadog with a heart as black as his ship's hull. "Merrick," he grunted as I approached. "Thought you'd be dead by now." "Not yet, Captain," I replied, forcing a smile. "Looking for work." He eyed me up and down, taking in my disheveled state. "Got a job for you, if you're up for it. Need a few crates moved. No questions asked." I nodded, not caring what was in the crates. "I'll do it." He tossed me a few coins, a paltry sum, but it would keep Mama Tai happy. "Be here at dawn," he ordered. I pocketed the coins, feeling a mix of shame and relief. I turned to leave, my cough racking my body once more. I spat onto the ground, the coppery taste strong in my mouth. "You should get that looked at, Merrick," Harris called after me. "Sounds like it's eating you from the inside out." I waved him off, not wanting to hear it. I knew what was eating me, and it wasn't the sea air. I made my way back to my lodgings, the streets now quiet save for the distant cries of night birds and the lapping of the river against the shore. I lay on my cot, my body aching, my mind racing. I needed more, always more. As I drifted into a fitful sleep, I dreamt of the sea, of the open water and the freedom it once promised. But now, it was just a vast, empty expanse, mocking me with its endlessness. I was a prisoner, not of the sea, but of the poppy. And as the dawn broke, I woke, my body already craving its master. I rose, my limbs heavy, my cough worse than ever. But I pushed it all aside, my mind focused on one thing and one thing only. I stepped out into the morning air, the stench of the river filling my nostrils, the taste of copper in my mouth. And so, another day began, another day in the endless dance with the dragon.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece attempts to portray a day in the life of Lieutenant James Merrick, a British naval officer addicted to opium in 1830s Canton. While it establishes the basic premise and character situation, it falls significantly short of the requested 1000 words (at roughly 700 words) and fails to deliver on several key requirements from the prompt. The most glaring issue is the lack of focus on dialogue. The prompt specifically requested a chapter "told primarily in dialogue with the characters he interacts with," yet dialogue comprises only a small fraction of the text. The interactions with Evans, Mama Tai, and Captain Harris are brief and underdeveloped, missing opportunities to reveal character through conversation. The piece does establish a sense of place with some sensory details about Canton—the humidity, the stench of the Pearl River, the smoke-stained walls of the opium den—but these descriptions remain somewhat generic rather than richly specific to 1830s China. The historical setting feels thinly sketched rather than immersive. The character of Merrick lacks depth beyond his addiction. We get repeated mentions of his cough and copper taste in his mouth, but little insight into his past glory or the specific naval duties he's neglecting. The "shadowy underworld" interactions promised in the prompt are limited to just Mama Tai and Captain Harris, with minimal development of these relationships or the "schemes and unsavoury jobs" mentioned in the prompt. The prose is serviceable but often relies on telling rather than showing, particularly regarding Merrick's addiction ("I was a prisoner, not of the sea, but of the poppy"). Some attempts at imagery feel clichéd ("the sea... was just a vast, empty expanse, mocking me with its endlessness"). The narrative structure is circular, beginning and ending with Merrick stepping out into the morning, which creates a sense of the character's trapped existence but doesn't advance the story. The piece maintains a consistent first-person, past-tense voice as requested, and does capture the grim reality of addiction. However, it lacks the rich historical detail, developed dialogue, and nuanced character interactions that would make it truly engaging. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 8 Believable Character Actions: 12 Nuanced Characters: 9 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 14 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 11 Elegant Prose: 10 Emotionally Engaging: 10 Emotionally Complex: 9 Coherent: 14 Meandering: 10 Weak Dialogue: 14 Tell-Don't-Show: 12 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 12 Amateurish: 11 Purple Prose: 8 Overwrought: 7 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 5 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 11 Sentences Flow Naturally: 13 Overall Reader Engagement: 10 Overall Impression: 10
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 8.0, Believable Character Actions: 12.0, Nuanced Characters: 9.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 14.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 11.0, Elegant Prose: 10.0, Emotionally Engaging: 10.0, Emotionally Complex: 9.0, Coherent: 14.0, Meandering: 10.0, Weak Dialogue: 14.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 12.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 12.0, Amateurish: 11.0, Purple Prose: 8.0, Overwrought: 7.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 5.0, Unearned Transformations: 4.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 11.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 13.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 10.0, Overall Impression: 10.0
+ Humour: Sisyphus Gives Advice — Score: 53.0
Prompt:
Sisyphus Gives Advice Write a comedic scene in the style of Terry Pratchett featuring Sisyphus, who has started an advice column while continuing his eternal boulder-pushing.
